title: How to Make Strawberry Macarons

steps.headline: Understand your ingredients.
steps.description: It is imperative that your measurements be as close to accurate as possible. Macarons are a very fiddly dessert that require a lot of precision. You may find it easier to measure your ingredients by weight (digitally if possible), instead of with cups (as is standard in North America). For this recipe, you will need a measuring tool that can calculate grams. Macarons utilize egg whites, which can be one of the most difficult ingredients to master and use both safely and effectively. Separating egg whites is quite difficult. It is very important that none of the egg yolk is mixed in with the whites; otherwise, the meringue will not whip and the cookie shell will not properly form. Specific tools made to separate egg yolks and whites are often readily available. If it is not possible for you to obtain a specific separating utensil, then read How to separate an egg for instructions on how to properly procure the egg whites from your eggs.

steps.headline: Preheat the oven to 325ºF /170ºC.
steps.description: Line a large baking sheet or tray with greaseproof paper or parchment (baking) paper. If the baking sheets are small, you may need to line two.

steps.headline: Place the icing (powdered) sugar and almond meal in a food processor.
steps.description: Pulse until you have created a very fine dust. Sieve through the mixture to remove any large chunks, discarding any remains that haven't passed through the sieve, before returning the mixture back into the food processor.

steps.headline: Measure out 85 grams of the egg whites.
steps.description: Pour into the food processor, along with the mixture. Blend the mixture and the measured egg whites to create a paste.

steps.headline: Place the sugar and water in a heavy-based saucepan (a saucepan with a thicker base designed to evenly distribute heat).
steps.description: Heat the mixture until the sugar has dissolved and it forms a syrupy consistency.

steps.headline: Mix the remaining 90g of egg whites in a mixer with a whisk attachment.
steps.description: Whisk until they appear light and fluffy and form soft peaks. Then, whisk in the red food colouring with the mixer, and gradually mix in the syrup in small increments. Continue whisking until the mixture has stiffened and appears shiny. Then transfer it to a clean mixing bowl.

steps.headline: Fold the almond mixture into the meringue with a large metal spoon.
steps.description: It is essential that you fold and not stir it!

steps.headline: Spoon the mixture into a piping bag with a 1cm nozzle.
steps.description: Pipe circles around 4cm in diameter onto the baking trays (previously lined with baking paper). Then, lift the baking tray off the surface and knock the bottom against the counter or surface, controlling your motions carefully to prevent it from spilling. (This flattens the macaroons and removes air bubbles from the meringue).

steps.headline: Place the macaroons in the preheated oven.
steps.description: Bake for about 12-15 minutes, or until the shells are firm. Leave the oven door slightly ajar. After removing the baked macarons from the oven, allow them to cool on wire baking racks. Once cooled, they can be filled with the strawberry buttercream (see next).

steps.headline: Prepare the ingredients.
steps.description: These are outlined above.

steps.headline: Begin by finely chopping the large strawberries before pressing them through a fine sieve to make a puree.
steps.description: Use the back of the spoon to push the strawberry pieces through into a mixing bowl.

steps.headline: Beat the butter in a mixing bowl with a paddle attachment until it is light and fluffy.
steps.description: Using a whisk attachment, whisk in the icing sugar and strawberry purée until fully blended.

steps.headline: Spoon the mixture into a piping bag.
steps.description: To make each macaron, pipe the buttercream onto the flat surface of a macaron half and sandwich it shut with the flat surface of another macaron half. Continue until all are made.

steps.headline: Serve.
steps.description: The macarons can be served after making or stored chilled in an airtight container for two to three days. They are best consumed within 12 to 24 hours.

methods.name: Strawberry Macarons with White Chocolate Ganache

steps.headline: Prepare the baking sheets (trays).
steps.description: Line one to two baking sheets with parchment or baking paper. This recipe makes 15 to 20 small macarons, so the amount of baking sheets needed will depend on their size.

steps.headline: Place the icing (powdered) sugar into the flour sifter.
steps.description: Add the almond flour. Sift into the mixing bowl.

steps.headline: In a separate bowl, prepare the egg whites.
steps.description: Whisk the egg whites and salt together until the mixture forms firm peaks. Add the caster (superfine) sugar and powdered pink food colouring. Whisk until the meringue mixture turns glossy and shiny.

steps.headline: Add the almond flour to the meringue mixture.
steps.description: Use a spatula to stir the almond flour with the egg whites, lifting the mixture upward as you stir. Do not overwork the mixture; it should appear somewhat lighter but not too bright.

steps.headline: Transfer the meringue and almond mixture to the baking sheet.
steps.description: Use a piping bag to pipe small, neat and evenly sized rounds onto the prepared baking sheet(s). Keep them as much the same size as possible and space them evenly. Set aside to stand for 1 hour at room temperature.

steps.headline: Preheat the oven 10 minutes before baking.
steps.description: Preheat to 150ºF (300ºF) fan-forced, 170ºC (375ºF) conventional.

steps.headline: Place the rested macarons into the preheated oven.
steps.description: Bake for 12 minutes. Remove from the oven and allow to cool completely before handling.

steps.headline: Purée the strawberries.
steps.description: See How to Purée Strawberries for information on doing this if you're unsure what to do.

steps.headline: Add the white chocolate to a small saucepan with a heavy base.
steps.description: Melt over a low heat. A double boiler can be used if preferred.

steps.headline: Pour the strawberry purée into the melted white chocolate mixture.
steps.description: Stir to combine. Remove from the heat and allow to cool down to room temperature before using.

steps.headline: Spread the ganache on one half of a macaron.
steps.description: Gently press down another half onto the ganache to sandwich the two halves together. This forms the first macaron. Repeat with the remaining macaron halves until all have been created.

steps.headline: Serve.
steps.description: The macarons can be served after making or stored chilled in an airtight container for two to three days. They are best consumed within 12 to 24 hours.

text: Strawberry Macarons Understand your ingredients. It is imperative that your measurements be as close to accurate as possible. Macarons are a very fiddly dessert that require a lot of precision. Macarons utilize egg whites, which can be one of the most difficult ingredients to master and use both safely and effectively. Separating egg whites is quite difficult. Specific tools made to separate egg yolks and whites are often readily available. If it is not possible for you to obtain a specific separating utensil, then read How to separate an egg for instructions on how to properly procure the egg whites from your eggs. Preheat the oven to 325ºF /170ºC. Line a large baking sheet or tray with greaseproof paper or parchment (baking) paper. If the baking sheets are small, you may need to line two. Place the icing (powdered) sugar and almond meal in a food processor. Pulse until you have created a very fine dust. Sieve through the mixture to remove any large chunks, discarding any remains that haven't passed through the sieve, before returning the mixture back into the food processor. Measure out 85 grams of the egg whites. Pour into the food processor, along with the mixture. Blend the mixture and the measured egg whites to create a paste. Place the sugar and water in a heavy-based saucepan (a saucepan with a thicker base designed to evenly distribute heat). Heat the mixture until the sugar has dissolved and it forms a syrupy consistency. Mix the remaining 90g of egg whites in a mixer with a whisk attachment. Whisk until they appear light and fluffy and form soft peaks. Then, whisk in the red food colouring with the mixer, and gradually mix in the syrup in small increments. Continue whisking until the mixture has stiffened and appears shiny. Then transfer it to a clean mixing bowl. Fold the almond mixture into the meringue with a large metal spoon. It is essential that you fold and not stir it! Spoon the mixture into a piping bag with a 1cm nozzle. Pipe circles around 4cm in diameter onto the baking trays (previously lined with baking paper). Then, lift the baking tray off the surface and knock the bottom against the counter or surface, controlling your motions carefully to prevent it from spilling. (This flattens the macaroons and removes air bubbles from the meringue). Place the macaroons in the preheated oven. Bake for about 12-15 minutes, or until the shells are firm. Leave the oven door slightly ajar. After removing the baked macarons from the oven, allow them to cool on wire baking racks. Once cooled, they can be filled with the strawberry buttercream (see next). Prepare the ingredients. These are outlined above. Begin by finely chopping the large strawberries before pressing them through a fine sieve to make a puree. Use the back of the spoon to push the strawberry pieces through into a mixing bowl. Beat the butter in a mixing bowl with a paddle attachment until it is light and fluffy. Using a whisk attachment, whisk in the icing sugar and strawberry purée until fully blended. Spoon the mixture into a piping bag. To make each macaron, pipe the buttercream onto the flat surface of a macaron half and sandwich it shut with the flat surface of another macaron half. Continue until all are made. Serve. The macarons can be served after making or stored chilled in an airtight container for two to three days. They are best consumed within 12 to 24 hours. Strawberry Macarons with White Chocolate Ganache Prepare the baking sheets (trays). Line one to two baking sheets with parchment or baking paper. This recipe makes 15 to 20 small macarons, so the amount of baking sheets needed will depend on their size. Place the icing (powdered) sugar into the flour sifter. Add the almond flour. Sift into the mixing bowl. In a separate bowl, prepare the egg whites. Whisk the egg whites and salt together until the mixture forms firm peaks. Add the caster (superfine) sugar and powdered pink food colouring. Whisk until the meringue mixture turns glossy and shiny. Add the almond flour to the meringue mixture. Use a spatula to stir the almond flour with the egg whites, lifting the mixture upward as you stir. Do not overwork the mixture; it should appear somewhat lighter but not too bright. Transfer the meringue and almond mixture to the baking sheet. Use a piping bag to pipe small, neat and evenly sized rounds onto the prepared baking sheet(s). Keep them as much the same size as possible and space them evenly. Set aside to stand for 1 hour at room temperature. Preheat the oven 10 minutes before baking. Preheat to 150ºF (300ºF) fan-forced, 170ºC (375ºF) conventional. Place the rested macarons into the preheated oven. Bake for 12 minutes. Remove from the oven and allow to cool completely before handling. Purée the strawberries. See How to Purée Strawberries for information on doing this if you're unsure what to do. Stir to combine. Remove from the heat and allow to cool down to room temperature before using. Spread the ganache on one half of a macaron. Gently press down another half onto the ganache to sandwich the two halves together. This forms the first macaron. Repeat with the remaining macaron halves until all have been created. Serve.
